This happens on SSL-only server.

I see many error log:

child process XXX exited with status 3221225477 -- Restarting.

Hey ApacheLongue! Can't you just provide 2.4.9 again so I can downgrade ASAP!?

2.4.10 has a serious bug like this.
https://issues.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=56795

https://www.apachelounge.com/download/VC11/binaries/httpd-2.4.9-win32-VC11.zip
This is empty :(
creator: b231438@drdrb.net
trawick@apache.org
text:
Even though the name might lead you to believe otherwise, this is not "Apache Lounge", which is not affiliated with the ASF.

Please contact Apache Lounge (apachelounge.com) on the availability of particular binaries on their site.

It is possible that mod_whatkilledus/mod_backtrace (http://emptyhammock.com/projects/httpd/diag/index.html) could provide us more information about the crash.  Unfortunately, I don't think that the Apache Lounge installs normally have .pdb files, so function names would be mostly bogus.

creator: b231438@drdrb.net
text:
Hey Jeff, thanks for a comment!

> this is not "Apache Lounge"

about it here.

2.4.9 Server are working as normal. Only 2.4.10 cause this issue.

> Exception code: 0xc0000005
> Fault offset: 0x01250c5c
> Faulting process id: 0x940

I believe this OFFSET can tell you where (*.c) is causing problem. Wish you're doing good bug hunting.

> mod_whatkilledus/mod_backtrace (http://emptyhammock.com/projects/httpd/diag/index.html)
I downloaded it. Let's see what I can do to provide more...

P.S. I want 2.4.9 :'( *sob*

text:
I understand it is likely an Apache httpd bug, but you're yelling this into the wrong forest:

>Hey ApacheLongue! Can't you just provide 2.4.9 again so I can downgrade ASAP!?

Hopefully the bug will be fixed soon-ish AND you'll get the binary you want.

creator: b231438@drdrb.net
text:
Um... here you go...

> [core:error] [pid 4612:tid 676] AH00546: no record of generation 1 of exiting child 4324
> [backtrace:warn] [pid 4324:tid 560] Symbol files are not present in the server bin directory; backtraces may not have symbols
> [mpm_winnt:error] [pid 4324:tid 832] (OS 10038)An operation was attempted on something that is not a socket.  : AH00333: WSAEventSelect() failed.
> [mpm_winnt:error] [pid 4324:tid 828] (OS 10038)An operation was attempted on something that is not a socket.  : AH00332: winnt_accept: getsockname error on listening socket, is IPv6 available?
> [mpm_winnt:error] [pid 4324:tid 1424] (OS 10038)An operation was attempted on something that is not a socket.  : AH00333: WSAEventSelect() failed.


Socket error? Probably.

Firefox says:
"The connection was reset
The connection to the server was reset while the page was loading."

creator: b231438@drdrb.net
text: AH00333: WSAEventSelect() failed. ---> ./server/mpm/winnt/child.c:347

creator: trawick@apache.org
text:
>Um... here you go...
>
>> [core:error] [pid 4612:tid 676] AH00546: no record of generation 1 of exiting child 4324
>> [backtrace:warn] [pid 4324:tid 560] Symbol files are not present in the server bin directory; backtraces may not have symbols
>> [mpm_winnt:error] [pid 4324:tid 832] (OS 10038)An operation was attempted on something that is not a socket.  : AH00333: WSAEventSelect() failed.
>> [mpm_winnt:error] [pid 4324:tid 828] (OS 10038)An operation was attempted on something that is not a socket.  : AH00332: winnt_accept: getsockname error on listening socket, is IPv6 available?
>> [mpm_winnt:error] [pid 4324:tid 1424] (OS 10038)An operation was attempted on something that is not a socket.  : AH00333: WSAEventSelect() failed.

>Socket error? Probably.

- AH00546: ignore for now
- "Symbol files are not present...": This means that if a crash occurs (not something indicated in this error log snippet), a backtrace from the crash will have some invalid function names in it, making it hard to debug.
AH00333, AH00332: setup problem related to sockets when trying to start a new child process

I need to see more of the error log, such as what happened before this, timestamps, etc.  You can send it to trawick@gmail.com with subject "PR 56808" if you can't attach it here.

creator: trawick@apache.org
text:
I don't think httpd processes any of the interesting data in the testcase.  I didn't encounter any problem with my 64-bit build of 2.4.10 + php 5.5.15.

Maybe I'll have a chance tomorrow to test with ApacheLounge 32-bit 2.4.10.

Have you tried it without mod_security loaded?

Which PHP are you using?  (version, and where was binary obtained)

creator: b231438@drdrb.net
text:
> Have you tried it without mod_security loaded?

What the...
If I disable(un-comment) them, problem solved.

Why mod_security2 & uniqueid modules cause problem in 2.4.10?
It's working with NO PROBLEM since 2.4.9!

creator: b231438@drdrb.net
text:

(In reply to Whatt from comment #12)
> > Have you tried it without mod_security loaded?
> 
> What the...
> If I disable(un-comment) them, problem solved.
>

creator: covener@gmail.com
covener@gmail.com
text:
> Was it necessary to uncomment both? What clued you into mod_unique_id?

err "comment both"

creator: b231438@drdrb.net
text:
> Was it necessary to uncomment both? What clued you into mod_unique_id?

Actually, mod_sec2 require mod_uniqid. That's why I uncomment it.

I tested it again - this time, I don't uncomment mod_uniqid.
And problem solved.

===
Conclusion:

Only mod_sec2 is causing problem. It works on 2.4.9, but NOT 2.4.10.

iReportIt ---> https://github.com/SpiderLabs/ModSecurity/issues/766

creator: trawick@apache.org
text:
>Why mod_security2 & uniqueid modules cause problem in 2.4.10?
>It's working with NO PROBLEM since 2.4.9!

Unfortunately that probably can't be answered until the exact bug is found :(  Some bugs are sensitive to memory layout or other non-bug changes of surrounding software.

If infinite time were available we could continue investigating, but httpd doesn't parse the data that causes the problem whereas mod_security can (and presumably does in your configuration).  You might try disabling mod_security features to see if you can find a specific trigger, and update the mod_security bug with that information.  (shrug)

This bug report may still cover a unique httpd issue, probably related to recovering after the POST crash:

> [mpm_winnt:error] [pid 4324:tid 832] (OS 10038)An operation was attempted on something that is not a socket.  : AH00333: WSAEventSelect() failed.
> [mpm_winnt:error] [pid 4324:tid 828] (OS 10038)An operation was attempted on something that is not a socket.  : AH00332: winnt_accept: getsockname error on listening socket, is IPv6 available?
> [mpm_winnt:error] [pid 4324:tid 1424] (OS 10038)An operation was attempted on something that is not a socket.  : AH00333: WSAEventSelect() failed.

It would be good to see more of the error log to understand the sequence of events.
Whatt, please e-mail me off-line at trawick@gmail.com.  I'm not able to contact you via your e-mail address here.

creator: b231438@drdrb.net

text:
This is not an appropriate venue to discuss the mod_security issue that you opened.  Ask for status on the Github issue that you opened.

Additionally, you are abusing the free service we provide here and using it to publish information that we have already deemed inappropriate.  That is absolutely unacceptable.

I'm marking this bug as resolved/invalid because, as far as we can tell at this time, it is a mod_security issue and there is nothing to research on the Apache httpd side.
creator: trawick@apache.org

text:
(In reply to Whatt from comment #23)
> Created attachment 31881 [details]
> Apache 2.4.10 POST result to crash | test sample for everyone!

I'm assuming it's not fit because the policy is to not post the full details of vulnerabilities to bugzilla while they are still under investigation.  

If you continue to be needlessly belligerent, you're just likely to get less and less help from the volunteers here in resolving your issue (or even losing access to bugzilla)
